title: Top lawyer found dead below cliffs had been suspended over 'sexual behaviour'
text:

A top lawyer was found dead at the bottom of a cliff face had been suspended from work for allegations of inappropriate sexual behaviour.

Geraint Thomas kissed his wife goodbye and said "I'll see you later, I'll be home by 7.30pm", before leaving for work on December 17 last year.

At his law firm, the 47-year-old was called into a private meeting and told he was being suspended while a formal investigation was carried out.

Mr Thomas vanished after leaving the office in Cardiff and was found dead hours later, an inquest heard.

Rebecca Thomas said her husband had been the "happiest and least stressed" she had seen him in the lead up to his death as the family planned a three-week Christmas trip to East Australia.

(Image: Athena Pictures)

She said: "To say Geraint was looking forward to the trip would be an understatement."

The family had celebrated an early Christmas at their home in Radyr, Cardiff, ahead of the trip.

On the weekend before Mr Thomas' death he showed "no signs" of work worries.

On Monday, December 17 last year, he kissed his wife goodbye before attending a meeting where he heard of his suspension.

Mrs Thomas said: "I have no doubt that whatever was said at that meeting was fundamental in Geraint's change of mind and subsequent actions later that day."

The inquest heard Mr Thomas was found in Southerndown near Bridgend, South Wales, on December 18 - a spot where his family previously enjoyed walks together.

Mrs Thomas said she became concerned when her husband did not respond to a string of text messages - and a security guard at his Eversheds Sutherland law firm said his car was not there.

Firm partner David Watkins then told her to "call police and file a missing person report."

But Mrs Thomas believed this advise was an "overreaction" because she was unaware of the full details of the meeting that had taken place.

(Image: unknown)

The inquest heard that the "allegations of inappropriate sexual behaviour" related to two social events, including one Christmas party.

Mr Thomas was "calm and professional" as he received the news.

He told HR chiefs: "I will collect my things and go."

Mr Thomas, who was found at the foot of the cliff, had shown no previous signs of mental health problems.

The Oxford University graduate was a partner at law firm Eversheds Sutherland and specialised in offering Brexit advice to businesses.

A profile on the company website said fluent French speaker Mr Thomas had been a partner since 2003 and was an expert in consumer credit and mortgage regulations.

The inquest in Pontypridd, South Wales, continues.
